Award.AwardTitle: Development of Ultra-low Loading Platinum Alloy Cathode Catalysts for PEM Fuel Cells: Theoretical and Experimental Studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0966956
Popov

The proposed research will establish a scientific and engineering basis for the development of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell cathode catalysts having ultra-low Pt loadings and increased durability for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). These catalysts are expected to have fast reaction rates and good stability that are essential for developing next generation fuel cells for sustainable energy systems.

Intellectual Merit

Hybrid cathode catalysts (HCC) will be synthesized using a carbon composite catalyst (CCC) with an ultra-low loading of Pt. The CCC has a high content of active pyridinic nitrogen sites, and will be used as a support for ultra-low loading of platinum instead of carbon black, which is currently used in the commercial catalysts. Besides its own contribution to the overall catalyst activity, the noble metal free CCC will enhance the activity of Pt and Pt alloys (e.g., Pt-Co/CCC, Pt-Fe/CCC, Pt-Ni/CCC) through synergistic effects.

A first-principles mathematical model and density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be used to help understand the oxygen reduction kinetics on the HCC catalysts. Structure-property relationships will be established using a wide range of electrochemical and surface characterization techniques. These studies will create a framework for the development of novel synthesis procedures to prepare highly active and stable catalysts for ORR with ultra-low Pt loading.

Broader Impacts

Given the world's low platinum reserves (30,000 tons of unproven reserves), the hybrid cathode catalyst (HCC) proposed in this study has the potential to reduce both the cost of the PEM fuel cell and consumption of this precious metal.

Interdisciplinary courses at both the graduate and undergraduate levels in quantum chemistry & material surface characterization, as well as materials science & electrochemical engineering, will be developed. Programs will be developed to accelerate the transition from passive learners to scientists and engineers by training students in group-based problem solving, helping students acquire technical and time management skills, and by challenging them to complete a project related to electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction. In addition, the program will increase community awareness of next-generation energy technology and career opportunities, and promote the involvement of students from under-represented groups in these activities.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project entitled “Development of Ultra-low Loading Platinum Alloy Cathode Catalysts for PEM Fuel Cells: Theoretical and Experimental Studies” addresses the research program in critical areas of energy research to raise the quality of fundamental research in PEM fuel cell cathode catalyst development. First-principles based models developed in this study led to a better understanding of the transport mechanisms at the catalyst and Nafion® membrane interface. Our experimental and numerical analyses revealed that a decrease of Pt loading resulted in a substantial change in the catalyst layer structure and the mass transport processes. With the help of fractal dimension theory, we identified that the particles form a smooth layer with separated agglomerates and small agglomerate size when the fractal dimension is close to 3. The developed model also indicated that the volumetric agglomerate density is the highest due to the closely packed non-agglomerated particles deposited on the Nafion® membrane. Simulation of the experimental results obtained from H2/O2 and H2/air PEM fuel cell operation revealed that the high inner surface area of the agglomerates/particles resulted in a very thin Nafion® film covering the catalyst particles thus decreasing the diffusion resistance. The effectiveness factor is the smallest because of the high tortuosity of the catalyst layer. The tortuosity increased the Thiele modulus at low catalyst loading and decreased the effectiveness factor. The addition of more and more catalyst enhances the agglomeration in the catalyst layer. The fractal dimension decreased the volumetric density of the agglomerates and the mass activity of the catalyst. However, it enhanced the diffusion in the gas phase.  

            The Department of Chemical Engineering at USC is hosting two NSF-funded REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) sites. During the project period (03/01/2010 – 02/29/2013), three REU students were working on the project under the program. In summer 2012, Brian Murphy (Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA), conducted research on the “Development of ultra-low Pt loading hybrid cathode catalysts for PEM fuel cell” and won the First Prize at the REU presentation competition. The outcome of his summer research resulted in two co-authored publications which are published in ECS (Electrochemical Society) Transactions.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2013
Modified by: Branko N Popov

First-principles based models developed in this study led to a better understanding of the transport mechanisms at the catalyst and Nafion® membrane interface. Our experimental and numerical analyses revealed that a decrease of Pt loading resulted in a substantial change in the catalyst layer structure and the mass transport processes. With the help of fractal dimension theory, we identified that the particles form a smooth layer with separated agglomerates and small agglomerate size when the fractal dimension is close to 3. The developed model also indicated that the volumetric agglomerate density is the highest due to the closely packed non-agglomerated particles deposited on the Nafion® membrane. Simulation of the experimental results obtained from H2/O2 and H2/air PEM fuel cell operation revealed that the high inner surface area of the agglomerates/particles resulted in a very thin Nafion® film covering the catalyst particles thus decreasing the diffusion resistance. The effectiveness factor is the smallest because of the high tortuosity of the catalyst layer. The tortuosity increased the Thiele modulus at low catalyst loading and decreased the effectiveness factor. The addition of more and more catalyst enhances the agglomeration in the catalyst layer. The fractal dimension decreased the volumetric density of the agglomerates and the mass activity of the catalyst. However, it enhanced the diffusion in the gas phase. During the project period (03/01/2010 – 02/29/2013), three REU students were working on the project under the program. In summer 2012, Brian Murphy (Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA), conducted research on the "Development of ultra-low Pt loading hybrid cathode catalysts for PEM fuel cell" and won the First Prize at the REU presentation competition.
